sentence: Retail companies are usually the last sector to report during earnings season and Home Depot is one of the last major retailers to report, giving its announcement earlier today.
Home Depot ( HD ) reported an increase in profit and revenue in the third quarter that beat estimates by Wall Street analysts.
Yet, despite the positive news on the earnings front, the stock is currently down over one percent on Tuesday trading close to $96.50 per share.
As the world's largest home improvement retailer, Home Depot is a good indicator of how US consumers are spending their money this coming holiday season.
Despite Home Depot's latest investigation on their Payment Data Breach, Home Depot reported that net income rose 14% to $1.5 billion in the third quarter, or $1.15 a share.
Their reported earnings beat the Zacks consensus estimate of $1.13 per share which was already calling for 18.95% YoY growth in EPS.
That compares with $1.4 billion, or 95 cents a share, in the same period a year ago.
The home improvement company reported sales of $20.5 billion for the third quarter of fiscal 2014, a 5.4 percent increase from the third quarter of fiscal 2013.
Comparable store sales for the third quarter of fiscal 2014 grew 5.2 percent, and comp sales for U.S. stores were up 5.8 percent.
"During the quarter we saw strong performance across all geographies led by growth in transactions and continued strength in the core of the store," said Craig Menear, CEO and president.
"I would like to thank our associates for their hard work and dedication to our customers, and I would like to thank our customers for their continued confidence in The Home Depot."
The company expects fiscal 2014 sales growth of approximately 4.8 percent.
HD also confirmed that it expects fiscal 2014 diluted earnings per share to grow by 21 percent to approximately $4.54.

This earnings-per-share guidance includes the benefit of the company's year-to-date share repurchases of $5.74 billion and the Company's intent to repurchase an additional $1.26 billion of shares in the fourth quarter.
The earnings-per-share guidance also includes an estimate of net breach-related costs of approximately $34 million for the year.
On November 6th, The Home Depot found additional findings related to the recent breach of its payment data systems.
• Criminals used a third-party vendor's user name and password to enter the perimeter of Home Depot's network.

These stolen credentials alone did not provide direct access to
• The hackers then acquired elevated rights that allowed them to navigate portions of Home Depot's network and to deploy unique, custom-built malware on its self-checkout systems in the U.S. and Canada.
• In addition to the previously disclosed payment card data, separate files containing approximately 53 million email addresses were also taken during the breach.

These files did not contain passwords, payment card information or other sensitive personal

The company has implemented enhanced encryption of payment data in all U.S. stores.
The new security protection locks down payment card data, taking raw payment card information and scrambling it to make it unreadable and virtually useless to hackers.
Home Depot is a very important retail store for investors to get a good consensus on how consumers are dealing with current market conditions.
Since the US is mainly a consumer driven market where 70% of the GDP is driven by consumer spending, the world's largest home improvement store is something investors need to take seriously.
The world's largest improvement store reports strong financial statistics and has been growing since 08' while showing steady growth in revenue, EPS, and net income.
We currently rank the home improvement store as a Zacks Rank #3 (hold) due to a mixed level of earnings estimate revisions in the past year.
HD has beat the consensus by an average of 4.66% in the past year and is expected to report earnings of 89 cents per share for the quarter ending in January which is a 22.55% growth in YoY terms.
